awd_titl_txt: Report on the Nation's Undergraduate Mathematical Sciences Programs:  Year Fifty of a Longitudinal Survey of Two-year and Four-year Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project contributes to the national interest by increasing understanding of undergraduate mathematical sciences programs across the United States.  This project will continue a cross-sectional, longitudinal survey of undergraduate mathematical sciences programs that has been done every five years since 1965.  The comprehensive survey is endorsed by the Conference Board for the Mathematical Sciences (CBMS), an organization whose members are the presidents of the seventeen professional associations in the mathematical and statistical sciences.  Consistent with previous CBMS surveys, the CBMS 2020 Survey will track changes in the curriculum, pedagogy, and enrollment levels by individual courses, bachelor's degrees granted, and program faculty. A comprehensive report will be developed to describe the survey results, thus providing current national benchmarks about the Nation's mathematical sciences departments.  The CBMS 2020 Survey Report will be distributed in spring 2020 to science policy leaders at the national level and to all U. S. mathematical sciences programs.  It will also be freely available online and in print. The findings of the survey will be promoted to the mathematical sciences community at professional meetings and in publications. Improving the Nation's undergraduate STEM efforts depends on improving undergraduate mathematics and statistics, and planning future reforms begins by knowing the present. The survey report will provide data on crucial issues within the mathematical sciences community, catalyzing other educational research.

The statistical design of the stratified random sample survey and associated statistical analysis will be conducted by statisticians at Westat, Inc., who will work in consultation with a steering committee appointed by CBMS. The final report will be written by the project's senior personnel and published by the American Mathematical Society. The survey's evolving structure will contribute to educational survey research methodology. In addition, the CBMS 2020 Survey will include topics of current importance to leaders concerned with undergraduate education in the mathematical sciences. Examples of topics include: (1) evidence-based teaching practices; (2) practices in distance-learning courses; (3) instructional strategies in College Algebra, Calculus I, and Elementary Statistics; (4) instructional strategies and delivery methods in developmental mathematics; (5) assessment of mathematics and statistics programs; (5) data on gender and under-represented groups; (6) undergraduate research and internship opportunities in the mathematical sciences; and (6) full-time faculty at four-year departments who not eligible for tenure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Conference Board of the Mathematical Sciences (CBMS) 2021 survey provided a comprehensive, sample-based study of global and fine-grain characteristics of the population of some 2,700 undergraduate two-year mathematics and four-year mathematics and statistics programs across the United States. Guided by a steering committee of faculty and administrators from these institutions, the PIs for the project established a set of questionnaires for these three departmental domains that explore such topics as: 

  • Course enrollments by mathematical subject and instructional methodology 

  • Characteristics of bachelors programs and degree recipients 

  • Characteristics of course sections and instructional staff 

  • Faculty demographics 

  • Special topics  

  

In addition to tracking many of these factors longitudinally through prior CBMS Surveys, conducted every five years since 1965, the new Survey examined a number of special situations, including the impact of COVID-19 on undergraduate mathematical sciences education, curricular innovation, distance learning, and dual enrollment. 

Subcontractor Westat, Inc. provided the technical and infrastructure support needed to conduct the study so as to optimize its statistical significance. The company was involved with every phase, starting with advising the steering committee and following through with question validation, form testing, sample selection, programming, sending the questionnaires, follow-up on non-response, data cleaning and validation, and preparation of tables. 

Additionally, RMC and RW Jones were contracted for final data cleaning and validation and the preparation of tables for further analysis by the PI for the final report.  

The final report, Statistical Abstract of Undergraduate Programs in the Mathematical Sciences in the US, by R. Blair and E. Kirkman will be published and released in February 2025. Following is a brief selection of findings detailed in this report. 

 

CBMS is one of the few national surveys that covers mathematical sciences in two-year colleges (2YCs). The survey instrument was sent to a random sample of 228 2YCs selected from the 1,008 institutions in the US with two-year math programs. Approximately 76 of the sampled departments responded. Here is a small, illustrative selection of the findings in the final report: 

  • Between 2015 and 2021, 2YC enrollment in mathematics fell by 28% to 1.33 million. 

  • Between 2015 and 2021, 2YC enrollment in statistics and probability courses decreased by 8% to 257,000 students. Calculus-level courses showed a 1% decrease to 151,000.  

  • Fall 2021 enrollments in distance/remote learning courses across 2YC mathematics departments surpassed those in non-distance/remote courses. Specifically, enrollments in precalculus, introductory-level courses, Calculus I and II, differential equations, linear algebra, and introductory statistics combined was estimated at 646,669 students, three and a half times the estimate of 184,618 in 2015. 

  • An estimated 71% of 2YC mathematics departments have offered “Pathways sequences courses” in the last five years, compared to 58% in the CBMS 2015 survey. 

  • In 2021, for the first time since 1975, there was a 3-percentage-point decrease in the proportion of women among full-time permanent mathematics faculty at 2YCs. Women now represent 49% of full-time permanent faculty, while men make up 51%. This marks a shift from the 2015 CBMS survey, where 52% of full-time faculty were women and 48% were men. 

The CBMS Survey covers mathematical sciences departments in four-year colleges and universities in the US (4YCUs). This sampling frame includes 1,655 bachelors-, masters-, and PD-granting programs that offer degrees in mathematics, applied mathematics, statistics, mathematics educations, actuarial science, computer science, and joint majors with other academic areas. These programs were stratified by degree offerings, and in academic year 2021, a total of 394 departments were sampled of these, a total of 160 responded. Here are a few details regarding 4YCUs: 

  • The total number of students earning bachelors degrees from all mathematical sciences departments at 4YCUs decreased by 14%. 

  • Between fall 2015 to 2021, the total number of full-time faculty at four-year mathematics departments increased by 41%, and part-time faculty increased by 31%. 

  • Women comprise an estimated 37% of all full-time mathematical sciences faculty, 30% of all tenured faculty, 37% tenure-eligible faculty, 45% of other full-time faculty, and 24% of postdocs, compared to fall 2015 where 22% of tenured faculty were women and 22% of postdocs were women. 

Overall, the CBMS Survey paints a picture of increasing diversity in course options and curricular pathways for them tailorable to career goals and needs of other disciplines, a shift toward course delivery by instructional staff who have non-tenurable and part-time appointments, and increasingly inventive pedagogical strategies.
